Amos GohLevel 3. WonderkidAnswered on 13 Apr 2018I think it differs from person to person. Yes, different banks give consumers different interest rates but these often come with strings attached. These criteria / conditions sometimes erodes your capital and this might end up causing you not to save any money.For example, if you are a fresh graduate, you must have salary crediting and overcome several hurdles before you can hit the interest of around 2% for DBS Multiplier. In contrast, a SSB would be in the ballpark of a 10 year-guaranteed 2% rate for $500-100K.0 comments6

WizardAnswered on 13 Apr 2018Yeah I think this is a common thought process and good question when thinking about Bonds vs low-interest rate other products (eg Fixed deposits or Endowments or High savings rate account or even CPF SA.) I would say there are many similarities but when you are talking about liquidity, both the DBS Multiplier account (or even other high savings rate accounts) and SSB do best. :DBut take into consideration that I believe many people go for SSB if they do not qualify for the many terms and conditions (T&C) for the high-interest rate savings account.
